bestBHT.bht: The disciples, in awe of their Master's power, immediately found themselves at their intended destination. The wind, recognizing the presence of its Creator, grew weary and exhausted itself, bringing about a calm. In worshipping Him, the disciples acknowledged His divinity, while the wind's stillness further displayed His power. Both winds and sea proved themselves obedient to their Lord, establishing His dominion over them.

Henry Alford: 32.] John (vi. 21) adds “and immediately the ship was at the land whither they went:’—see note there.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: 32. And when they had come into the
boat, the wind ceased—(Also see on :-.)
Albert Barnes: He that has power over winds and waves has all power.
The ship was immediately at the land whither they went; another proof, amid this collection of wonders, that the Son of God was with them.
They came, therefore, and worshipped him, acknowledging him to be the Son of God.
Marvin Vincent: Ceased [εκοπασεν] . A beautiful word. Lit., grew weary; sank away like one who is weary.
Philip Schaff: John (John 6:21) speaks of the boat being immediately ‘at the land whither they went’
This was on the western side of the lake
We may either suppose that the wind during the night had driven them near that shore, or accept another miracle
Archibald T. Robertson: The wind grew weary or tired, exhausted itself in the presence of its Master.
Not a mere coincidence that the wind ceased now.
The wind ceased in the presence of its Master.
John Gill: The wind ceased: from blowing with that fury and violence it did before, and there was a perfect calm.
Which gave equal proof of the divine power of Christ, as his walking upon the sea.
Both winds and sea obey him, who is Lord of both.

bhtAttempts.bht: The disciples, in awe of their Master's power, boarded the boat and immediately found themselves at their intended destination. The wind, recognizing the presence of its Creator, grew weary and exhausted itself, bringing about a calm. This was not a mere coincidence, but rather a testament to the authority that Jesus held over all creation. In worshipping Him, the disciples acknowledged Him as the Son of God. The wind's cessation was another sign of His divinity, just as significant as His ability to walk on water. In that moment, both the winds and the sea proved themselves to be obedient to their Lord.

The disciples, in awe of their Master's power, immediately found themselves at their intended destination as the wind grew weary in the presence of its Creator. This cessation was not a mere coincidence, but a testament to Jesus' authority over all creation. In worshipping Him, the disciples acknowledged His divinity, while the wind's stillness further displayed His power. Both winds and sea proved themselves obedient to their Lord, establishing His dominion over them.
